awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Vision-guided Control of Robust Perching: From Biological to Robotic Flyers
awd_abstract_narration:
In a blink of our eyes, a fly can perch upside-down on a ceiling by executing a sequence of well-coordinated maneuvers triggered and controlled by a brain no bigger than a pinhead. This project aims to unravel how the robust intelligence of this process emerges from a synergistic combination of computational and mechanical processes, and how can they be translated to robotic flyers through an integrated biological and robotic investigation. Small robotic flyers suffer universally from high energy consumption and low aerodynamic efficiency.  Robust perching will significantly extend small robotic flyer's functioning time and expand their applications such as environmental and disaster monitoring, aerial surveillance, and search and rescue. The project will also introduce biological and robotic locomotion principles to students and the public through visually appealing insect flights and robotic perching experiments, creating an ideal educational framework for STEM students of all ages.

For small flyers, animals and robots alike, orchestrating a successful perching in dynamic and uncertain environments is one of the most challenging aerobatic feats. To land safely, a flyer has to solve a distance-velocity-attitude sensing and control problem with limited computational resources and under stringent time constraints. This project will first use targeted insect experiments with artificially-manipulated visual cues to reveal the computational processes that coordinate different maneuvers of perching in blue bottle flies, and how the computation takes into account dynamic physical environments and mechanical processes. Guided by the results from the biological perching, this project will accomplish robust robotic perching on stationary or moving surfaces using a centimeter-scale quadcopter. This will be achieved by developing computationally-efficient vision algorithms to extract essential visual information to control the robot's velocity and orientation prior to touchdown so that the robot can firmly attach to the desired surfaces with biomimetic compliant legs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
In an era where robotics and biological sciences increasingly intersect, this project has advanced our understanding of the robust perching capabilities of biological flyers and the emulation of similar capabilities in robotic systems. This research has opened new dimensions in small-scale aerial robotics, making substantial contributions to the field by intertwining mechanical and computational intelligence.

Our research aimed to unravel how small flyers, both biological and robotic, achieve robust landing with limited sensing and control capacities. For robotic flyers, we developed novel algorithms and mechanisms inspired by biological flyers, particularly focusing on vision-based triggering and control for landing maneuvers. Key outcomes include 1) the creation of time-to-contact based trajectory generation methods, allowing robotic flyers to achieve non-zero contact velocity essential for robust perching; 2) the development of innovative perching mechanisms, such as fully passive grippers that require no actuators to close or open for perching or releasing, respectively; 3) the integration of computational and mechanical Intelligence to facilitate autonomous perching in small-scale flying robots. These advancements have not only deepened our understanding of the mechanical and computational intelligence in aerial robotics but also paved the way for practical applications in various fields.

The project's outcomes extend beyond the scientific community, fostering interest and education in STEM fields. We actively engaged in public outreach through events like the Little Shop of Physics open houses, demonstrating our findings to K12 students and the general public. This interaction helped in sparking curiosity and interest in robotics among young minds.

Educationally, the research has been integrated into courses like "Biologically Inspired Robotics" and "Mechatronics," enriching the curriculum with practical, cutting-edge examples. These courses, blending theory with real-world applications, have been well-received by students, enhancing their learning experience and preparing them for future challenges in engineering and robotics. The project also contributed to human resource development in science and engineering. Graduate, undergraduate, and high school students involved in the project received hands-on research experience and mentoring, fostering their growth as future scientists and engineers. The professional development of a postdoctoral researcher further underscores our commitment to nurturing talent in academia.

From elucidating the complexities of biological perching to translating these insights into robust robotic systems, this project has made significant contributions to both the understanding of natural processes and the advancement of technological applications. The project's success lies not only in its scientific discoveries but also in its impact on education, public engagement, and the nurturing of the next generation of researchers and engineers. The knowledge and techniques developed through this award will influence future research directions and inspire innovative solutions in the fields of robotics and beyond.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Jianguo Zhao
